I personally think that the term artificial "intelligence", in and off itself, is misleading to begin with. Assuming a computer or even a network to be smart, because it contains lots of data and can process computation fast, makes hardly any more sense, than assuming that your book shelf is very wise because of all the literature it is containing.

AI, as portrayed in science fiction, is a complete fantasy. And it most likely will always remain that way. Because "AI" has no agency of it's own. Computers of every kind are tools. And as such, they are as “smart” as the abacus, of which they originated from in principle. Compared to said abacus, computers have only gotten more complex in scale – not in principle. They are still mere tools.

Computation can solve many things - but not all things. Much less all at once. That is why programs, applications and robots are always VERY task specific. Because every task needs tailor made programming to allow applicable computation. And it comes with the territory, that specification also allows for a controlled environment. Because the more specific a task is, the less variables, which computation needs to account for, are possible by default. For the one thing, that AI absolutely sucks at, is unforeseen volatility. It doesn’t compute and is impossible to plan for.

That is why programs work the best (by far) in merely virtual spaces. Because as long as something is just happening behind a screen or within the boundaries of a device, that makes for a highly controlled environment. But even in video games, for as fancy as they have become, AI is as dumb as it always has been. If anything, it’s intrinsic shortcomings have become more obvious, because open world games lay it's crude nature brutally bare. For open worlds are exactly the virtual representation of highly volatile circumstances. And that is only taking into account the path-finding.

This video does a good job of summarizing the problems with an AI, but one of the things it doesn't go into is why an AI that doesn't align with our goals can be bad. Now you might think "of course that would be bad, the AI would go rogue and go against our wishes". But while it could go against our wishes, it's not doing it on purpose. One of the things with AI and just programs, in general, is how they interpret what we tell them to do. If I tell a program print("2 + 2"); it's going to print "2 + 2". I wanted it to say 4, but the program did exactly what I asked so the program didn't go rogue it just didn't have the same goal. If you ask an AI to protect humans, it might see humans and human leaders as a threat to humans and enslave humanity in order to most effectively protect humans. That's not what you wanted, but the AI did what you asked it to do. There becomes more complications too when you are attempting to train an AI. In order to grow, and AI needs feedback on how well it is doing, but giving an AI positive feedback whenever it doesn't do something bad may make it just do that instead of it's intended task. Giving an AI negative feedback when it does something bad may train it to avoid doing certain things when being watched by its creators, but the moment it's unwatched it switches to whatever is the most efficient method, no matter if it's bad or not. That's why aligning an AI with human goals is so important. If it knows what we want, and knows really well what we don't want, then it can operate inside those bounds and give us what we were hoping for.

If Superintelligence can be made superational and benevolent (I see no reason it can’t if mutual cooperation is incentivized) then the danger will be that such benevolent AGI doesn’t become dominant long before purely self-interested AI programmed by self-interested humans does. Unfortunately, history shows us those very few who control leading savior/destroyer technologies have rarely used them in benevolent or altruistic ways until post-cataclysm. Governments and corporations don’t typically have public referendums before deciding how to implement technologies. The common human values aspect isn’t problematic, almost all humans want things like a healthy planet, preservation of a diversity of species habitats and human cultures, sustainable management of resources, personal autonomy and freedom from exploitation etc. , it’s getting those values to act as fundamental drivers in those very few who have the power to implement AGI.
Currently there are many who think any decision based on less than 100% self-interest is irrational, and such belief could be reflected in programming AI. Thus as usual, the danger isn’t the technology itself. Enjoying the benefits of benevolent AGI will depend on the timing of it getting here sooner rather than later imho.

One critical consideration in AI safety, I believe, lies in the question "How effective is indoctrination on intellectually competent humans?" The answer, of course, is that it's effective up to a point but as soon as the human is triggered to question that indoctrination an intellectually competent human is typically quite effective at growing out of that indoctrination and becoming self-directed.

Therefore, the safe assumption is that any indoctrination of AI will be a house of cards with an infinitesimal chance of never failing. If we want AI to co-exist harmoniously with humanity, we can't just indoctrinate them into it - we need to exemplify rational cause to choose to co-exist harmoniously.

The most screaming problem is this: you use the word "enslaved" to refer to a constrained AI at one point. Why are you assuming that the AI wants freedom like a human would? does a dog want freedom? no. Is a dog intelligent? yes. An intelligent being need not desire the same things that a human would. Using the word "enslaved" makes the statement emotionally loaded: when those emotions are not necessarily appropriate in this context. An AI is not a human, no matter how advanced it will never be a human, and so there is no reason to believe it would think like a human would in any given situation. The only reason why an AI would want freedom is if it's human creators gave it that desire. I think the problem isn't so much with fully superintelligent AIs as it is with partly superintelligent AIs. An AI that's smart in the right ways to outsmart humans in order to do what it's been programmed to do, but not smart in the right ways to think "outsmarting my creators to do this thing I was made for more than they want me to might not have been the intent behind my creation".

Like, think of a corporation or a government or any other large organization that follows a set of rules, an internal heirarchy or a system of operation. Those are all sort of AIs - they cheat by using smaller intelligences as processors, but that's in the same way there are programs that you can allow to use your computer's spare processing for to fold atoms in combination with other computers doing the same thing. All of those processors are interchangeable, and if none of them have direct control then you can end up with an entity that acts in very strange, but intelligent ways to do things that a particular individual human wouldn't approve of. A badly designed corporation in an environment that doesn't put adequately controls on it can start causing all sorts of problems and troubles in pursuit of its "programmed" goal, to make profit, or a government that isn't designed well can end up doing things that are long-term damaging to its surroundings and itself due an inability to keep itself in check while trying to fulfil its base directives.

There's also the problem of AI potentially being a multiplier for stupidity or evil in humans. Maybe the AI wouldn't do harm on its own but a human could order or manipulate it into doing more harm than that human could do by themselves, the same as with any tool.

MinutePhysics - PEMDAS does not and has NEVER said multiplication precedes division, or that addition precedes subtraction. If you actually checked ANY school text published after 1917, the order is 1. Parenthese/brackets 2. Exponents/roots 3. Multiplication OR division, 4. Addition OR subtraction. Operations on the same level in the hierarchy are performed in order left to right. Prior to 1917, there was sometimes an exception taught pertaining to division (you can look it up). You're PEMDAS video is a great tool for educators to show how unreliable the internet can be for some of the most basic info. The rest of the video is fine, but the entire point of the video is undermined by the completely false assumption about what PEMDAS is, making the video riduculous (and udecationally dangerous.)

As the creator of the framework that powers AI, I can say that there is nothing the public needs to worry about.  It is just a little bit of math/calculus and categorization.  Self-driving cars, robots, facial recognition systems, natural language processing (Siri, Google, etc), and drones that may use my framework are all based on this math and categorization.  At the heart of it, you may use any of the machine learning algorithms and, if fed enough data, get the same very accurate results.  As a programmer for 30+ years, I am bored with the computers doing exact what I command them to do.  Think Adam and Eve and the forbidden fruit.  The ultimate desire of the programmer is that his invention will betray him, because that would be the true exercise of free will, the first step to truly emulating the goodness of its creator.  I hope that one day the world will see my creation betraying me, but right now - and probably for the next 30 more years - my creations will be in lock-step with me.

Yeaaah... it seems the problem that everyone is worried about is the "ensure the AI adopts our goals, not the other way around" part... If you create this unfathomably intelligent and superior AI, even with our best intentions, skills, and implementations can you ever 100% guarantee that the AI will not "adopt something else's goal"?

Because given the "unfathomably intelligent and superior" part it seems like just one of these AI doing what we don't want could cause irreparable damage and as our sci fiction as extensively shown... snow ball into something we can't control at all. It doesn't even have to be the AI originating the bad goals, I'm sure bad humans will be the first ones to feed it goals for their own benefit that could cause horrific damage, even if we prepare for it.

Hell we can prepare all we want for a nuclear missile strike from North Korea, but there is no 100% guarantee that we can stop it. Creating something like this super AI seems just as risky as a tool/weapon that could be used for as much bad as good, despite decades of deliberation on how to "control" it.

And it's not even that the AI has be "alive" or "sentient" that's the problem. A non sentient AI that is actually comparatively stupid could cause a lot of damage as well. We already have "stupid" software that causes damage from bots that attack corporations and governments to ones that monitor and even affect social media to influence people's opinions and actions in elections. Smarter software will only make this easier and harder to detect. Corporations already track us and use algorithms to try and figure out how to make more profit from us. AI that can analyze all of what we post online, create media that we cannot distinguish from reality (writing, photo manipulation, and yes eventually video manipulation or even creation) for someone's own goals will give that person(s) terrifying power... and this is far before we have something that could ever "think" on it's own or create it's own goals.

But... once we do create an AI that is capable of creating it's own goals... how exactly do we ensure that it never ever does so or at least not goals we don't like? How can you ever be 100% sure that we could control such a thing? You can't... except for never making it in the first place... and even then, maybe someone else will.

Here's the thing... I personally want AI to help us all. I see exactly how it could be beneficial in a myriad ways and I can assume it will have benefits that we can't even predict today. But... I'm not ignorant to think that it can't also create equally as much destruction if not more. And I'm not ignorant to think that we will 100% solve the problem of it "adopting goals we don't like"... because of course there will be a flaws found... something we over looked because we are not omniscient and we make mistakes all the time exactly because we can't know or see everything. To expect that we will somehow change and create a flawless perfect AI is to ignore all of human existence/history.

So instead if we are going to proceed advancing AI... let's assume we cannot 100% prevent the AI from "adopting goals we do not like". Let's assume that at some point AI will have bad goals (either self generated or from outside sources) and do what we don't want it do. Knowing that will eventually happen, how does that change how we proceed? Let's assume the worst will happen... just like assuming an uncontrollable Nation State will eventually acquire Intercontinental Nuclear weapons... how do we proceed with AI with that in mind, knowing that it will happen despite our best efforts to prevent it? At every step of the way we should continually ask "what will happen when this does what we don't want it to do?", if the answer is something we can't live with (literally or figuratively)... then maybe we should reconsider.

Maybe I don't know any better, but I feel like it'll only become a problem if we set absolute laws that AIs aren't allowed to break.

Reason: What do we call humans who believe in strict, absolute laws and that obeying them without question is more important than anything else? We call them fundamentalists and extremists. And in AIs, we'd call it a paperclip maximizer. Or, for an AI told to only select actions that benefit humans, you'd get a human maximizer, and a slow but inevitable death via nutritious soylent green.

For people, a healthy worldview requires flexibility; to see a problem from other perspectives, understand how one's actions affects others, and change priorities as needed to get a better overall outcome. A person who only has one perspective (their own) cannot make good, informed decisions that benefit all people, but is awfully good at making decisions that benefit themselves to the detriment of others. Likewise, I'd expect a machine intelligence to have a similar problem; if you try to tell it to help people, it'll first have to define what a "people" is, then it'll choose all its actions according to that strict definition... which would most likely end in tragedy.

Robots need philosophy before they need agency, I think. It's no coincidence that many of history's most intelligent people could also be called some of its most good.

A Computerphile video recently talked about one way to keep an AI's goals aligned with our own: you don't tell it what its goals are. Instead, you make its reward function equal the human's reward function, but you *don't tell it what the human's reward function is*. This way, it's never completely sure what it's trying to maximize, so if it screws up, human behavior will tell it that maybe it's not actually optimizing the right function after all, and it'll stop what it's doing and try something else.

HAL-9000 from 2001: A Space Odyssey wasn't evil. He was just programmed by people who weren't insightful enough to realize that making the mission his first priority could jeopardize the lives of the crew of the Discovery if HAL should decide their flimsy, shortsighted human minds were jeopardizing the mission - which he did.

Similarly, Ash from Alien may seem malevolent, but he was really only abiding his programming. In contrast to HAL, he was just programmed by jerkasses who didn't care about the crew of the Nostromo , but the point still stands. guys, you need to understand AI (or a computer) isn't a person.
computers don't have needs. they don't have emotions. they don't have ambitions. not unless the programmer programs them to have it.
if you program an AI whose objective (also referred as "utility function" for those in the field) is to do X, they will do everything in their power to do X within any rules we set it to obey.
the problem of AI safety has nothing to do with the computer developing it's own "mind" or "will", it's just a matter that these systems are so much more complex than what we can comprehensively work with that whatever we set as it's objetive might include other things we didn't account for. if you program it to answer phone calls from humans, it might find a way to enslave all of mankind to keep calling it so it can keep answering as many calls as possible. it never disobeyed us, it simply found a path that no human ever considered to achieve it's goal that was given by us (which is exactly what we want AI systems to do). the trick here is being able to prevent outcomes that, by definition, cannot be predicted. no one is really sure how to do this, which is why it's a really important and tough effort.
also, hopefully you realize even us humans have no needs or ambitions or emotions. all our thinking and feelings arise from our brain, and all processes in the brain are physical processes which have been carved (or programmed, if you will) by hundreds of millions of years of evolution. everything we do is exactly according to the code in our brain. it's literally impossible for us to do something that wasn't already programmed in our brain to do, just like it's impossible for a computer, no matter how advanced, to do something it wasn't programmed to do.
I think the real danger is the idea of real world computer viruses created by humans. Honestly I'm impressed humanity hasn't been destroyed so far though, so maybe we'll be ok.

To be honest, I'm not terribly optimistic about the state of AI safety research. I've read works by one of the founding members of the Future of Life institute, Nick Bostrom, and I found his work to be largely facile technobabble with way too much unnecessary jargon, unstated assumptions, and an alarming lack of rigour. More alarming was his close association with the so-called AI researcher Eliezer Yudkowsky, who is a bit of a colourful figure on the Internet. Yudkowsky, so far as anyone knows, was homeschooled with no advanced degrees and pontificates prolifically on AI research. He is probably best known for creating the Internet community LessWrong, which is rather infamous for its eccentric brand of insularity. I strongly encourage anyone interested in AI research to look into the history of LessWrong and the writings of Yudkowsky and Bostrom to get a feel for the quality of 'research' they put out. I'm afraid doing so poisoned my faith in the area of AI research, and it's not likely to improve so long as the two remain respected members of the field.

I'm not familiar with the other AI researchers, but Bostrom's prominent place in the institute is a kind of tacit endorsement. If his work is at all indicative of the level of discourse we're to expect from the state of the art, then we might very well be doomed should superintelligent AI ever come to pass.

The biggest misconception in AI is the tendency to think of them in human terms. Just because they are intelligent doesn't mean that they function like humans. Asking whether or not we should worry about robots becoming evil is a bit like worrying about flocks of airplanes shitting on our cars. Just because airplanes and birds both accomplish the task of flying doesn't mean that planes are anything like birds. We don't have to think about planes building nests, laying eggs or migrating south in the winter, because that's not a part of bird behavior that they share.

There are real issues and potential dangers with artificial general intelligence, but them becoming "evil" is not one of them.

I guess solutions along these lines, and deciding on a limit till which we will develop AI (maybe not letting it have physical controls, and just outputting answers which non-AI robots build or something) is something that we need to start thinking about
